physDesc.p: This letter is one page. The word “Poetry” is handwritten in pencil on the top of the page and the name “Monroe” handwritten across from the date and above the start of the typed letter.

div.p: Thank you very much for your review in “Poetry.” I am kind of sorry that you put in that about learning, as above all things I don’t want people to get into their heads that I am academic and dry. And I know you did not mean to convey that impression; I only feel that perhaps it may a little.

But I am sorry you do not like my longer poems. It is very funny—reviewers seem equally divided between those who love them and those who detest them. It was very handsome indeed of you to say what you did about my vers libre, and altogether I am exceedingly obliged to you for putting it in so soon and for giving me such a nice sendoff.

Fletcher will be in Chicago soon. He is a dear boy when you know him well, and I think you will enjoy seeing him very much. I am giving him a letter to Miss Anderson. I don’t know whether I told you that Houghton, Mifflin & Company is issuing his “Irradiations” in book form.
I am longing to see the Lawrence war poem. He wrote me about it.
I find I am obliged to put off my visit to Chicago until after Christmas, which is too bad, but the work is so pressing here that I cannot get away before.
With all sorts of good wishes for your Christmas,
